image.altText: A head shot of a man in police uniform

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police commissioner Reece Kershaw was directly involved in meetings with PwC partner Mick Fuller, the former NSW police chief, to discuss a $750,000 contract awarded without a tender.

title.children: AFP commissioner accused of failing to declare conflict of interest after meetings with PwC 'friend'

image.altText: Tom Roper is dressed in a checked shirt and jacket as he sits in his wheelchair in front of a tram.

items.synopsis: The giant of the Victorian Labor Party, who served as a minister in the Cain and Kirner governments, is being remembered as a fierce social justice advocate, a hard worker, a reformer, an early campaigner for climate action, a mentor and a top bloke.

title.children: Long-serving Victorian Labor MP 'Snappy' Tom Roper dies aged 78

image.altText: Nicola Gobbo in black and white looks at the camera.

items.synopsis: Victoria's director of public prosecutions Kerri Judd has rejected criticism that she should have authorised criminal charges over the Lawyer X scandal.

title.children: Victoria's chief prosecutor hits back at claims she should have authorised Lawyer X scandal charges

image.altText: A dim, dark blue picture of a white submersible underwater, with a stream of bubbles coming from it.

items.synopsis: Authorities say the search for the submersible missing near the Titanic wreck is entering a critical stage, with fears the five occupants will run out of oxygen and develop hypothermia if not found soon. Follow live.

title.children: Search for missing submersible Titan enters critical stage, only hours of oxygen remain

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The time it has taken to load some of the heavy equipment needed for a potential rescue effort means there are still ships on the way to the search area, even as the Titan's oxygen supply is likely nearing its end. Among them are the Terry Fox, a Canadian Coast Guard icebreaker carrying search and rescue equipment, and the Horizon Arctic, a Canadian ship with a launch and recovery system for remotely operated submersibles, which is reportedly carring a US military vehicle.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Ships are still on their way to the search area

children.content: The time it has taken to load some of the heavy equipment needed for a potential rescue effort means there are still ships on the way to the search area, even as the Titan's oxygen supply is likely nearing its end.

Among them are the Terry Fox, a Canadian Coast Guard icebreaker carrying search and rescue equipment, and the Horizon Arctic, a Canadian ship with a launch and recovery system for remotely operated submersibles, which is reportedly carring a US military vehicle.

props.alt: A large red and white boat sitting in a foggy port.

children.content: CCGS Terry Fox prepares to depart St John's Port in Newfoundland on Tuesday, local time.
(Reuters)

props.alt: A large, sharp-looking blue boat sits in a foggy port.

children.content: The MV Horizon Arctic sits in St John's Port as equipment is loaded onto it by a US Air Force airlift.
(Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Boeing has told CNN it "was not a partner on the Titan and did not design or build it ", despite a 2021 news release from OceanGate listing the company as a partner that provided "design and engineering support". Similarly the University of Washington has told local media it was not involved with the design, engineering or testing of the submersible, despite a 2021 OceanGate court filing crediting the university for having taken part in "detailed engineering and development work". A spokesman said the university had worked with OceanGate from 2013 to 2020 on a different submersible called the Cyclops .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Boeing, University of Washington deny they helped design the Titan

children.content: Boeing
has told CNN it "was not a partner on the Titan and
did not design or build it
", despite a
2021 news release from OceanGate
listing the company as a partner that provided "design and engineering support".
Similarly the
University of Washington
has told local media

it was not involved with the design, engineering or testing of the submersible, despite a 2021 OceanGate court filing crediting the university for having taken part in "detailed engineering and development work".
A spokesman said the university had worked with OceanGate from 2013 to 2020 on a different submersible called the
Cyclops

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Oisin Fanning, CEO and Executive Director of San Leon Energy PLC has been on the OceanGate twice and says there may be more oxygen left on the submersible than expected. He told RN Breakfast this morning the passengers on board were professionals, and they would be rationing their oxygen. "They will be utilising their oxygen very sparingly," he said. "They will not be fast breathing, they will not be panicking." He said they have chemicals and blankets on board which help keep the carbon dioxide out of the air. "So I think that window of 20 hours that people keep talking about will not apply to these people. "I think they could easily get another 24 hours out of this." You can listen to RN Breakfast's full interview with Fanning at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former Titan passenger believes submersible could have more oxygen than anticipated

featuredLink.title: A glimmer of hope in the missing sub search - ABC Radio National

children.content: Oisin
Fanning
, CEO and Executive Director of San Leon Energy PLC has been on the OceanGate twice and says there may be more oxygen left on the submersible than expected.
He told
RN Breakfast
this morning
the passengers on board were professionals, and they would be rationing their oxygen.
"They will be utilising their oxygen very sparingly," he said.
"They will not be fast breathing, they will not be panicking."
He said they have chemicals and blankets on board which help keep the carbon dioxide out of the air.
"So I think that window of 20 hours that people keep talking about will not apply to these people.
"I think they could easily get another 24 hours out of this."
You can listen to RN Breakfast's full interview with Fanning at the link below.

image.altText: A white submersible vessel floating on a platform on water.

items.synopsis: A few days after a submersible with five people aboard has gone missing, a Canadian surveillance vessel has detected underwater noises, more narrowly defining the search area for rescue crews. But the question remains whether the noises came from the tourist submarine.

title.children: How likely is it that the noises detected underwater are coming from inside the missing Titanic tourist submersible?

image.altText: A composite image of Peter Genders and Janet with photos of building defects in the background.

items.synopsis: It's the biggest investment most people make, but in the "buyer beware" market, what you see is not always what you get, as these people found out.

title.children: Most of the buildings on Janet's new property are illegal. She says she didn't know

image.altText: An aerial view of cars packed into a suburban development.

items.synopsis: The Victorian government is accused of "hoarding" hundreds of millions of dollars for Melbourne's sprawling outer suburbs as communities in these areas struggle without basic amenities.

title.children: Victorian government accused of 'hoarding' funds for sprawling communities on city fringes

image.altText: An elderly man in glasses sits in front of a blank wall.

items.synopsis: Gerald Ridsdale appeared via video link from St John's Hospital at Port Phillip Prison, appearing very frail and significantly weaker than the last time he appeared in front of the court.

title.children: Fresh charge and guilty plea from one of Australia's most prolific paedophile priests

image.altText: Darrell Ray and the 1976 Moorabbin Cats.

items.synopsis: The former primary school teacher was charged following investigations into reports at a Victorian school.

title.children: Former St Kilda Little League coach to face court for historical child sex abuse charges

image.altText: a wide shot of a housing estate showing multiple properties

items.synopsis: New research suggests Australia's housing market will continue to recover from the 2022 downturn and reach new high prices by mid-next year, while more interest rate rises are likely on the way in the US and England. Follow live.

title.children: House prices to reach new record in coming financial year, rate hikes likely in US and UK, ASX down 1.5pc

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It was a subdued day of trading to say the least, with the ASX closing sharply lower, finishing down 1.6% to 7,196 points. There wasn't a sector that finished in positive territory, with academic and educational services shedding the most, down 4.1%. The technology sector was down 2.6%, while real estate dipped by 2.4%. That said, it wasn't all bad news — some companies finished the day with some modest gains. The top five performers for the day were: NRW Holdings +2.6% Telix Pharmaceuticals +1.8% Bellevue Gold +1.6% Collins Foods +1.5% Liontown Resources -1.4% The worst performers of the day were: Johns Lyng Group -11.9% Gold Road Resources -8.3% Megaport -8.2% Polynovo -6.2% Magellan Financial Group -6.2% That's it for today's markets blog — thanks for your company throughout what was a fairly muted day. Overnight, we'll find out what the Bank of England chooses to do with interest rates — although last night's inflation data suggests a 0.25 percentage point hike is pretty much confirmed. We'll have the roundup of the decision, and reaction from the markets overnight in tomorrow's blog. Until then, you can catch up on today's developments below, or download the ABC News app and subscribe to our range of news alerts for the latest.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX closes sharply lower as Johns Lyng and Gold Road Resources shares dive

children.content: It was a subdued day of trading to say the least, with the ASX closing sharply lower, finishing down 1.6% to 7,196 points.
There wasn't a sector that finished in positive territory, with academic and educational services shedding the most, down 4.1%.
The technology sector was down 2.6%, while real estate dipped by 2.4%.
That said, it wasn't all bad news — some companies finished the day with some modest gains.
The top five performers for the day were:
NRW Holdings +2.6%
Telix Pharmaceuticals +1.8%
Bellevue Gold +1.6%
Collins Foods +1.5%
Liontown Resources -1.4%
The worst performers of the day were:
Johns Lyng Group -11.9%
Gold Road Resources -8.3%
Megaport -8.2%
Polynovo -6.2%
Magellan Financial Group -6.2%
That's it for today's markets blog — thanks for your company throughout what was a fairly muted day.
Overnight, we'll find out what the Bank of England chooses to do with interest rates — although last night's inflation data suggests a 0.25 percentage point hike is pretty much confirmed.
We'll have the roundup of the decision, and reaction from the markets overnight in tomorrow's blog.
Until then, you can catch up on today's developments below, or
download the ABC News app
and
subscribe to our range of news alerts
for the latest.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Members from the Mining and Energy division have overwhelmingly voted to withdraw from the CFMEU to establish their own independent Mining and Energy Union. Last month the Mining and Energy Union members voted in a secret ballot, with 11,501 members (or 53% of those eligible) voting to split from the CFMEU, with 98% of ballots returned voting in favour of the divorce. "This result confirms the message we’ve heard from you over several years," the union's general president, Tony Maher said. "Members have told us they want a union that focuses entirely on the needs and challenges of mining and energy workers, while also working constructively and collaboratively within the broader trade union movement. "Since our National Convention in 2021 unanimously supported pursuing a ballot of members to withdraw from the CFMMEU, we have overcome numerous legal obstacles and delays. "I’m very pleased that members have now had their say and we are a major step closer to establishing an independently registered Mining and Energy Union." The Mining and Energy division have declared the ballot result to the Fair Work Commission, and will make an application to the Federal Court of Australia to seek orders for a withdrawal date in 30 days.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mining union votes to split from CFMEU

children.content: Members from the Mining and Energy division have overwhelmingly voted to withdraw from the CFMEU to establish their own independent Mining and Energy Union.

Last month the Mining and Energy Union members voted in a secret ballot, with 11,501 members (or 53% of those eligible) voting to split from the CFMEU, with 98% of ballots returned voting in favour of the divorce.
"This result confirms the message we’ve heard from you over several years," the union's general president, Tony Maher said.

"Members have told us they want a union that focuses entirely on the needs and challenges of mining and energy workers, while also working constructively and collaboratively within the broader trade union movement.
"Since our National Convention in 2021 unanimously supported pursuing a ballot of members to withdraw from the CFMMEU, we have overcome numerous legal obstacles and delays.
"I’m very pleased that members have now had their say and we are a major step closer to establishing an independently registered Mining and Energy Union."

The Mining and Energy division have declared the ballot result to the Fair Work Commission, and will make an application to the Federal Court of Australia to seek orders for a withdrawal date in 30 days.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It started lower but the ASX has continued to dive, down 1.5% so far today as of 1:10pm AEST. The sharp drop is thanks to a sell-off of stocks in the technology and mining space — WiseTech is down 3.9%, Carsales.com has shed 4.4%, and NEXTDC has fallen by 3%. As for miners, Gold Road is down 8.6%, and BHP has dipped by 2.1%, and BlueScope Steel has had a 2.9% decline. But there are some positive gains — here's the top five: Liontown Resources +2.2% NRW Holdings +2.2% Bellevue Gold +2% Telix Pharmaceuticals +1.1% Orora +0.9% Here's the worst five performers so far: Gold Road Resources -8.6% Magellan Financial Group -5% Megaport -4.4% Carsales.com -4.2% Polynovo -3.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX down 1.5pc at lunchtime amid tech and mining stock sell-off

children.content: It started lower but the ASX has continued to dive, down 1.5% so far today as of 1:10pm AEST.
The sharp drop is thanks to a sell-off of stocks in the technology and mining space — WiseTech is down 3.9%, Carsales.com has shed 4.4%, and NEXTDC has fallen by 3%.
As for miners, Gold Road is down 8.6%, and BHP has dipped by 2.1%, and BlueScope Steel has had a 2.9% decline.
But there are some positive gains — here's the top five:
Liontown Resources +2.2%
NRW Holdings +2.2%
Bellevue Gold +2%
Telix Pharmaceuticals +1.1%
Orora +0.9%
Here's the worst five performers so far:
Gold Road Resources -8.6%
Magellan Financial Group -5%
Megaport -4.4%
Carsales.com -4.2%
Polynovo -3.9%

image.altText: three images of a woman as an athlete, doctor and army training

items.synopsis: Jana Pittman is a world champion, doctor and mother - and suffers incontinence. She's one of the five million Australians that have continence issues.

title.children: Jana Pittman would tip water on herself every race to hide the fact she'd wet herself: She's not ashamed any more

image.altText: woman standing in tiny house kitchen

items.synopsis: As rents skyrocket and homelessness worsens in Victoria's Mount Alexander Shire, the council is removing permit requirements for some non-permanent dwellings.

title.children: Council eases restrictions on tiny houses, caravans and tents in bid to ease housing crisis

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese and Adam Bandt, both in dark suits, ties and spectacles

items.synopsis: The delicate relationship between Labor and the Greens often swings from confrontation to cooperation. But this week, during the stand-off over the government's housing bill, something snapped, writes David Speers.

title.children: Labor and the Greens aren't strangers to conflict. But in this week's housing stand-off, something snapped

image.altText: Businessman Yevgeny Prigozhin, left, stands next to Vladimir Putin and other men.

items.synopsis: As Russia moves to take control of Wagner with its push for recruits to sign contracts before July 1, Yevgeny Prigozhin, the head of the mercenary group, has vowed a boycott. Now everyone is waiting to see if he will ultimately bend to the Russian leader's will — and what happens if he refuses.

title.children: Putin appears to be feuding with his only friend. But nothing inside the Kremlin is as it seems

items.synopsis: The explosion was caused by a leaking petroleum gas tank at the restaurant, Chinese state media reports.

title.children: 31 dead in Chinese barbeque restaurant explosion

image.altText: A view from above of a field filled woth dirt and grass.

items.synopsis: The sanctuary, made up of ditches and burial mounds in the central Netherlands, is believed to have served a similar purpose to England's famous stone circle.

title.children: Archaeologists discover Stonehenge-like 4,000-year-old sanctuary in the Netherlands

image.altText: A pregnant woman lies on a footpath with a sign which says she is homeless, hungry, cold and asks for spare coins or notes.

items.synopsis: As the east coast endures a cold start to winter, there are calls for more to be done to help the growing number of people sleeping rough in New South Wales.

title.children: 'One of my homeless brothers died': Cold winter sparks fears for those sleeping rough in NSW

image.altText: A woman wearing a black tracksuit stands at the entrance to a retail store.

items.synopsis: She says the thefts range from someone slipping pencils into their pocket to people walking off with a trolley filled with $500 in decorations.

title.children: Thieves are stealing from Michelle's store every single day, as shoplifting bounces back in NSW

image.altText: A woman sits on a couch and holds a phone to her ear.

items.synopsis: An ombudsman report says too many telcos are failing to comply with the rules, and some of the rules are too soft, causing distress for phone and internet users.

title.children: 'The stress was incredible': Marina says her battle with Telstra proves the industry needs new rules

image.altText: A red Ferrari car with its door open

items.synopsis: Police seize luxury cars worth approximately $2.7 million after investigating what they allege is a cryptocurrency scam that defrauded two companies.

title.children: $600k Ferrari seized by police as alleged $5.5m Sydney cryptocurrency scam busted

image.altText: An alarmed woman wearing a bikini on a beach stands up as a dingo looks at her bottom.

items.synopsis: A young boy is the latest to fall prey to a dingo on K'gari, where thousands of tourists are expected to flock for the mid-year break. Authorities say the animals are exhibiting a concerning "level of dominance".

title.children: Boy, 10, dragged under water by dingo after French tourist, others attacked on K'gari (Fraser Island)

image.altText: A blonde woman wearing a yellow jacket standing in front of some ferns and a large tree

items.synopsis: As the end of native logging approaches in Victoria, Sarah Rees wants to see permanent protection of old-growth forests, but timber town residents disagree.

title.children: Environmentalists call for new national park near Melbourne to prevent future logging

image.altText: An elderly man sits in a rocking chair facing away into a sunlit garden, next to a vase of flowers on a table.

items.synopsis: The Salvation Army says electricity price rises for thousands of people on July 1 "will actually cause deaths", with things getting worse for many of the people relying on organisations like theirs to survive.

title.children: Victorian community workers fear energy price rises will mean people could die

image.altText: Two photos, on the left self photo of Jack Douglas Teixeira in uniform and on the right a sketch of him in court

items.synopsis: Jack Teixeira, 21, is facing up to 60 years in prison, charged with six counts of wilful retention and transmission of classified information relating to national security.

title.children: Suspected Pentagon Discord leaker pleads not guilty to six counts

image.altText: Three photo show the progression of baby Jarrod's illness. He gets more pale and has a red rash around his mouth.

items.synopsis: Senior staff at Caboolture Hospital had apologised to the child's parents after his condition was misdiagnosed and he was not admitted.

title.children: Investigation launched into hospital's treatment of baby with potentially life-threatening infection

image.altText: A man holds a kangaroo

items.synopsis: A man running a kangaroo sanctuary in South Australia's mid north is facing eviction, leaving a family and their rescued kangaroos without a home.

title.children: Kangaroo sanctuary owner faces eviction, meaning 90 rescued roos need a new home too

image.altText: An older Vietnamese woman cooks with gas on a wok in a kitchen

items.synopsis: The federal government's gas price cap is now acting as a floor according to major customers, and that's not good for consumers. So what can it do next?

title.children: Gas price cap 'overwhelmed by suppliers' strike'. So where to now for the government to limit energy price rises?

image.altText: Sunrise aerial shot of Lawn Hill Gorge in Boodjamulla National Park. Lots of pinks and purples on the skyline.

items.synopsis: Indigenous cultural sites have been damaged at Boodjamulla National Park (Lawn Hill) with the closure of the iconic travel hotspot putting a dent in an already-suffering tourism industry in outback Queensland.

title.children: Outback national park made famous by Chris Hemsworth ad remains closed

image.altText: Firemen use a water canon as they fight a blaze in Paris.

image.altText: Taylor Swift – slim, with straight blonde hair and wearing a legless leotard – sings into a mic during a live performance.

items.synopsis: Much to the disappointment of Swifties in the Sunshine State, Brisbane will miss out on the superstar's Eras tour. A stadium manager explains why.

title.children: Brisbane was 'definitely holding dates' at huge stadium for Taylor Swift, but she's not coming. Here's why

image.altText: A NSW Women's rugby league player races up the field as Queensland players try to tackle her in State of Origin.

items.synopsis: Over 15,000 people are expected to attend the clash in Townsville, making it the largest crowd for any women's Origin game.

title.children: Women's Origin decider to smash crowd record tonight

image.altText: A grey-bearded man in a singlet and shorts holds himself parallel on a pole

items.synopsis: When you picture a pole dancer, 62-year-old Allan Reinikka might not be the first person that comes to mind. But his skill has seen him appear on American reality television, and he's hoping the coverage encourages others to take up the sport.

title.children: This 62-year-old Australian pole-dancing sensation has just appeared on a US talent show, with hopes boosting the sport's profile

image.altText: Post-dip exhilaration for nude swim participants in red caps.

items.synopsis: With the air temperature dipping to just 3 degrees Celsius, it was a bracing start for the 2,000 people who ditched their gear and pitched into the River Derwent for the annual Dark Mofo nude swim.

title.children: 'So cold it burned': Rude shock for nude swimmers as Hobart puts on chilly start
